awd_titl_txt: Implicit Biases and Discretionary Prosecutorial Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Implicit Biases and Discretionary Prosecutorial Decision Making 

Abstract

In the United States, prosecutorial discretion provides criminal prosecutors with the ability to decide whether to pursue or dismiss initial criminal charges, and whether to negotiate a plea bargain. However, not much is known about the factors that may motivate prosecutors when they make these significant legal decisions, including whether any biases may influence their decisions. Understanding this decision-making process is particularly important when the crime involves intimate partner violence (IPV). This project will study and compare potential implicit biases in prosecutorial decisions in cases of IPV.

This project will employ an experimental approach with prosecutors recruited to participate. Measures will be taken to assess any explicit and implicit biases. In the experiments the prosecutors will then be provided with materials from the initial stages of an IPV criminal investigation, including the arrest report and witness statements. The gender and sexual orientation of the individuals involved in the alleged offense will be manipulated and varied. Prosecutors will then determine how they would proceed in the case, including whether to charge a felony or misdemeanor, and whether to offer a plea bargain. This multidisciplinary project engages theoretically in the psychology and criminal justice literatures. The research will provide insight into various influences on prosecutors when rendering decisions in IPV cases. As well, by offering a more comprehensive understanding of prosecutorial discretion, it has the potential to guide reform and improve practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the U.S. criminal justice system, prosecutors have enormous power and discretion in determining criminal charging decisions. While prosecutors rely on criminal law and case-specific evidence when making these decisions, we do not know the extent to which factors unrelated to criminal statutes also impact their case processing decisions. For example, prosecutors may be influenced by implicit attitudes, or unconscious beliefs people hold about social categories such as gender and sexual orientation. This research explored prosecutor decision-making in a case of alleged intimate partner violence (IPV). Within U.S. culture, IPV is pervasive and impactful, with more than one-in-three women and one-in-four men experiencing sexual violence, physical violence, or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime. As such, it is important to understand how prosecutors exercise discretion when processing these criminal cases.

Two-hundred and forty-one state and federal prosecutors from across the United States read an arrest file of a case of alleged intimate partner violence. The file included police reports, witness statements, and hospital records. The sexual orientation and gender of the intimate partner couple were manipulated, creating five different scenarios (opposite-sex couple/female victim; opposite-sex couple/male victim; same-sex couple/female victim; same-sex couple/male victim; sexual orientation/gender not specified). With the exception of gender and sexual orientation, the case files were identical and each prosecutor read only one file. Prosecutors then determined if they would proceed with criminal charges given the available evidence, what criminal statutes they would apply, and whether to proceed with plea negotiations. Prosecutors also completed measures of implicit gender role attitudes and implicit attitudes toward gay, lesbian, bisexual, and queer individuals, so that researchers could examine if these implicit attitudes are related to decision-making.

Victim gender and sexual orientation did not impact prosecutor decisions to file official charges or enter into plea negotiations. In addition, prosecutor implicit biases were unrelated to decisions. However, when the victim was female or in an opposite-sex couple, prosecutors were more likely to seek the severest criminal statute and propose the severest plea bargain. This suggests prosecutors do not consider victim gender and sexual orientation for substantial case processing decisions, such as whether to file charges. Instead, gender and sexual orientation may influence decision-making in more nuanced, yet nonetheless impactful, decision points.

This research also raises questions regarding the utility of the Implicit Association Test (IAT) within a legal setting. The IAT is a popular measure of implicit attitudes and IAT advocates have suggested it may be used in criminal justice settings to identify legal decision-makers who maintain negative implicit attitudes towards traditionally marginalized groups. However, at least within the context of prosecutorial discretion in IPV cases, prosecutor implicit attitudes were unrelated to their ultimate decision-making. As such, this research does not support calls for incorporating the IAT in criminal justice proceedings.

In addition to sharing these findings with the research community, results from this project have been summarized and shared in a popular magazine for district attorneys, increasing the impact of this research in real-world criminal justice settings.
